campaign.story:
Hail, and well met! I'm Jim Rodda, better known to the assorted scallywags, rapscallions, and ne'er-do-wells of the hobbyist 3D printing community as Zheng3.
My minor maker claim to fame is Seej, the Open Source tabletop war game based around 3D printing, but with this Kickstarter I'm trying something a little different.
I'm making Barbie-compatible 3D printed medieval armor.
It's important to note that I'm not now and never have been associated with Mattel, undisputed masters of Barbie and all her associated trademarks. I'm just some dude cranking out 3d models in his basement.
Barbie has had many occupations over her long and storied career. Astronaut, veterinarian, pinup, and princess more times than I can count. She has not, to my knowledge, cosplayed as Brienne of Tarth until now.
The field plate armor depicted in the photos and video above is a nice-enough prototype, good enough for patrolling the battlements at Stonemist Castle. But wearing it to a meeting of the Kingsguard? To the Council of Elrond? To prom? Honestly.
A fully funded Kickstarter will enable me to design and produce the next iteration of the prototype armor, a favolosa e bellissima ensemble that befits a lady of Barbie's high station.
Permit me to be crystal clear about two things:
1. My goal is primarily to distribute digital files for this armor; I'm happy to print rewards for backers but would prefer not to run a factory in the long term.
2. GIF is pronounced with a hard G, no matter what Steve Wilhite says.
The funding will cover the biodegradable plastic used to print the armor, replacement printer parts, and, most importantly, the time needed to design a highly detailed suit of armor, with all the engraving, ensorcelling, and enamelling Barbie's parade panoply deserves.

And test prints. Zounds, will there be test prints.
The armor will be distributed under a Creative Commons License. In a nutshell, you'll be able to modify, redistribute, and even sell the digital files and their derivatives as long as you credit the original designer. That's me.

Also note that I'm not selling Barbie dolls; if you want to use this armor you'll have to buy a Barbie Fashionistas Doll first.
If you've already got a 3D printer and know a doll that needs arming, head on over to The Forge and download a copy of the Athena Makeover Kit:
The spear and aegis should fit most dolls, although the winged boots are designed specifically for Barbie's feet.

While you're poking around The Forge, feel free to download a 3D squirrel or two. Be careful, some of them are armed.
Design and Protoyping
The inspiration for this armor came, indirectly, from my four-year-old niece. I wanted to print something unique for her next birthday, and so decided to design and engineer a pair of My Little Pony-compatible glitter cannons. (Note to self: next Kickstarter should involve My Little Pony-compatible glitter cannons.)

But! Moving parts and springs can be tough to do at this level of 3D printing, and after a few test prints I became frustrated and fell back on my usual method for generating new ideas: drinking three lattes and taking a hot shower.

Midway through my fourth latte, the idea to create 3D printed armor for Barbie sprang from my head, fully formed. Highly caffeinated and towel-clad I dashed over to the laptop and ordered a Fashionistas doll.
The design process is straightforward: photograph the doll from multiple angles and then use the photos as reference images in Maya, my 3D modelling package of choice.
The next step is printing a low-resolution test piece to see if it's a good fit on the doll. I'm doing all my prints on a Makerbot Replicator1, which has proven itself to be a reliable, if no longer bleeding-edge 3D printer.
(How about we all just let that last sentence sink in for a minute and realize we live in The Future?)
Finally, after many iterations and tweaks, print the piece at high resolution and call it good. Lather, rinse, repeat.
Barbie takes her fashion seriously, so it's important to get the fit just right. Here's our favorite model amid a pile of not-quite-snug-enough or just-a-bit-too-loose prototypes. Note the boot model in the lower left.
Funding Goal Reached, Stretch Goal Announced!
UPDATE! 3/28/14 
A huge thank you to all of Faire Play's backers! We've reached our initial funding goal with two weeks to go. I've been inspired by your generosity, and so I've created the Faire Play Recurve Bow as a digital token of gratitude for you all.
You can download the STL files for the bow from The Forge.

Stretch goal! If we can raise another $1000, I'll glamourize the bow and make it available on Shapeways so that anyone can make Babs deadly at a distance with a couple of clicks.
The Aegis Pendant
UPDATE! 3/20/2014
Bowing to popular demand I've introduced a new backer reward, the Aegis Pendant. It'll be 3D printed in your choice of metals: Antique Bronze Steel, Polished Gray Steel, or Polished Gold Steel. Thanks Shapeways!

Didja know you can 3D print in metal? Wowzers.
Backers at the $65 level will also receive the digital files for both suits of armor *and* the digital files for the Athena makeover kit. 

UPDATE: A metal proof of the pendant has arrived from Shapeways! Here's what it looks like in polished grey steel.
Production and Fulfillment Plan
Step 1: Model the parade armor and print prototypes.  April/May 2014
I expect this process to take approximately two months. I'll embellish the 3D model I've already created, adding every rivet, flourish, and bevel required to create a truly elegant suit of parade armor. I'll be test-printing prototypes and publicly documenting the process at Zheng3.com.
Those backers awake at around 5AM CST will be able to watch me work in quasi-realtime by gazing into the Scrying Pool at Zheng3.com.
Step 2: Print Athena Makeover Kit awards. April through August 2014
My 3D printer will dutifully churn out Makeover kits while I'm busy detailing the parade armor. At a rate of two kits a day I should have plenty printed by the time I need to deliver them to my backers. Then it's just a matter of boxing them up and shipping them out.
Step 3: Print parade armor for backers. June/July 2014
My experiments have shown that I can print roughly one suit of field plate in a day, though I expect the detail on the parade suits to require a little more time. I've intentionally limited the number of reward suits I'm shipping to a total of thirty, so we're looking at somewhere around a month and a half to get them all printed.
Step 4: Design custom shields for top-tier backers. July 2014
I'll be doing this step concurrent with Steps 2 and 3; while the printer is burbling away I'll be locked in my office with Illustrator, Photoshop, Maya, Science Friday podcasts, and three pounds of chocolate-covered espresso beans.

Step 5: Deliver the goods, digital and physical. July and August 2014

Digital rewards will be shipped first: a .ZIP file of the armor should still be small enough to fit in an email attachment.

I'm anticipating a few days of parcel stuffing and label-affixing before the physical rewards can ship. I'll be investigating shipping options throughout the production period.

The parade armor has filigrees, engravings, gewgaws, gubbinses, and assorted skeuomorphisms that will need to be designed so they can be printed with a minimum of fuss, but shouldn't affect the stability of the print.

House of Cards isn't releasing Season 3 until well after the Kickstarter is scheduled to finish, so that's eliminated as a potential source of delay.

campaign.story:
Table Titans is an ongoing online comic by Scott Kurtz that chronicles the adventures of Val Bronzebottom and her friends Alan, Andrew, and Darby as they embark on adventures at and away from the gaming table. The comic started in January 2013 and is currently in its second season. The purpose of this Kickstarter is to collect the first season of Table Titans into an elegant KICKSTARTER EXCLUSIVE hardcover book, for our fans who have shown us amazing support over the debut of our comic and for anyone who has just discovered us!
Table Titans celebrates the stories and memories we create with our friends while role-playing and is a love letter to the greatest role-playing game of all time, Dungeons and Dragons.
WHAT IF I'VE NEVER PLAYED D&D... OR ANY OTHER ROLEPLAYING GAME?! WILL I STILL LIKE THIS COMIC??
If you like high adventure, swords and sorcery, action, drama, comics, laughing and a whole lot of fun then Table Titans is for you! It DOESN'T MATTER if you've played D&D! No... seriously, it doesn't matter but don't be surprised if you makes you want to try it out! Whether you're a hardened RPG vet, a casual reader with a slight interest in the game, or if you think the whole thing is plain hooey, Table Titans, or any roleplaying game, is about telling good stories!
 TELL ME MORE ABOUT THIS BOOK!
Table Titans Volume 1: First Encounters is already finished and ready to print. In fact, If you like, you can go read the entire story right now online! Table Titans has already started its second major storyline, with a new page being posted online every Tuesday and Thursday.
Table Titans Volume 1: First Encounters collects season one of the Dungeons and Dragons inspired webcomic in print for the first time! This will be an oversized, full-color, action packed adventure featuring KICKSTARTER EXCLUSIVE cover treatment. That's right, the retail editions of Table Titans Volume 1: First Encounters will look completely different than the Kickstarter editions and you can only get the Kickstarter editions by being a backer!
When we first started the comic a year ago we had no idea the outpouring of love we'd receive from fans of the comic. Ever since we wrapped up the first season we've been getting asked about a print edition. So much so that it became clear to us that we NEEDED to Kickstart this book. Because alone we could print these comics but TOGETHER we can make a tome worthy of our fans!
UMMM... THAT BOOK LOOKS PRETTY NORMAL, HARDLY A "TOME" WORTH OF MY ILLUSTRIOUS BOOKSHELF!
Notice that "Designs Not Final" asterisk at the bottom there? That's because the book isn't designed yet. You see, if we'd done a design it's be a good book but with your help we can make it a great book. Our very first stretch goal features book design by the award-winning designer of the Scott Pilgrim and Sixth Gun series, Keith Wood!
UPDATE: Standard Edition Mockup from Keith Wood! (not-final)
Because our backers are amazing we funded almost immediately and got Keith started right away. He's already sent us a 3D mockup of the Standard Edition book! Please note that the art is not final but this is very close to what the cover and interior design will look like. We're hoping to have a mockup of the Deluxe Edition soon!
UPDATE: Deluxe Edition Concept Mockup from Keith Wood! (not-final)
Keith is on FIRE! We just got the concept of the Deluxe Edition and we're floored. It's a little hard to see in pics but that's PURPLE FAUX LEATHER with GOLD FOIL. Keith is also planning on adding lots of intricate details to the cover in the form of effects, deboss, and emboss, but they're not worked into the design yet. More pics coming 
WHOA, REALLY?!
Yeah, and it only gets better from there. With your help we can fill the books with extras, bonus content, and special features. Every penny we make from the Kickstarter will be going right back into the books.
BONUS CONTENT AND EXTRAS! LIKE WHAT? ELABORATE!!!
Well, we don't want to reveal all our goals at once but you might have noticed that there's a lot of content on the Table Titans website other than the comic. After all, the comic is inspired by a game. Plus, with Keith Wood potentially designing the book who knows what kinda crazy KICKSTARTER EXCLUSIVE cover treatments he's going to put in there. These books can only get better! We KNOW our fans can make this book amazing, let's turn Table Titans Volume 1: First Encounters from a one night adventure into a year long campaign.
SOUNDS GREAT, I LOVE BOOKS, BUT TELL ME ABOUT ALL THE OTHER LOOT!
OH HO! Adventurers after all, eh?! Well don't worry, we've got you covered with KICKSTARTER EXCLUSIVE tee-shirts, dice bags, even a 5" vinyl figure of Val the Barbarian, and for those Pinny Arcade collectors out there we've got a special pin just for you!
We're so fortunate to get to work directly with the folks at WeLoveFine.com and almost all of our rewards are being produced by them. Everything is in the design/prototype stages right now but we'll be posting updates, pics, and final versions on our backer blog so backers will get to see the whole process as it happens! 
I'M READY FOR ADVENTURE!
HUZZAH and thank you! Take a gander at the Reward Table below and back our book on the right. Together we're going to make an amazing book and a fantastic piece of art. Chose your rewards wisely and remember: "Titans never say die!"
 Scott Kurtz is an Eisner and Harvey award-winning cartoonist who helped pioneer online comics with his daily strip series Player vs Player, as well as a lifelong D&D player. Scott has been drawing in the margins of his character sheets for nearly thirty years. His love of art led him to devote his life to cartooning, but it was his love of storytelling that led him to create Table Titans.

Visit www.dungeonshare.com to check it out!
Introduction
Dungeon Share is all about helping Game Masters (GM) challenge their adventurers with dynamic and mentally engaging situations.  I've played in many tabletop games, and there is a stark difference in the player engagement when the GM has complex challenges for them to overcome.
This is not a computer program that is going to generate a dungeon, but rather a set of "modules" (effectively puzzle pieces) that a GM can mix and match to create an awesome adventure. They will not be system, level, or setting specific so that any GM can use them.
These modules will be put together by me, and by other tabletop veterans in order to aim for high quality.  All module suggestions will go through me (rather than letting users edit directly) in order to make sure everything stays in a specific order.  Those who help supply modules will be noted on that module's page if they desire.
At launch, Dungeon Share will provide the following modules (the terms I choose to use do not reflect a single type of tabletop RPG, although they arguably align most with D&D):
Challenges:  These modules are plot developments that characters must overcome.  They are the most overarching of the modules provided, and will often include smaller modules within them.  Challenges are an important resource for new GMs because they help prevent a GM from railroading his or her players.  The challenges on Dungeon Share will include a bunch of examples of possible routes for the players to take so that the GM can prepare for these possibilities beforehand (and maybe even give the players hints towards interesting routes).
Puzzles:  These modules are much smaller pieces of a game, and have the purpose of making the players think critically.  Unlike Challenges that focus on creative thinking, Puzzles force players to solve the situation in a very particular way.  New GMs will obviously find a great selection, but even veteran GMs will love finding puzzles that their equally veteran players have not seen yet (in fact, this very struggle is what led me to want to kick-start the site).  Puzzles work great is a classic dungeon crawl as a basic obstacle.
Encounters:  These modules revolve around how to make combat more interesting.  Some of my most tragic games have dragged on because every round of combat consisted of "I swing my sword at enemy A again".  Players need to have awe-inspiring battles if you want them to be truly engaged in a campaign.  These modules will provide good settings for battles, recommended enemy types for the setting, and subtle clues to give your players to promote creative fighting.
Creatures:  Closely related to encounters, these modules make sure that your players don't spend hours fighting legions of goblins that do nothing but swing basic weapons every round.  To engage players, you want enemies with powerful tactics that force them to be equally strategic.  These modules will provide interesting creatures, fun and engaging combinations, and ways to combine seemingly different creatures into the same plot.
Why Kickstarter?
I love everything about Kickstarter and truly think it should be the future of investing.  It builds more than capital, it builds a community of people who are willing to go the extra distance for their hobby. I personally believe that if this site is going to succeed, it needs the support of the tabletop playing community. In short, Dungeon Share requires a community to continue growing, and crowd-funding is the perfect way to find it. 
Stretch Goals:
Usually stretch goals are based on how much money a person is able to get to their kick-starter.  However, in the case of Dungeon Share, I don't care that much about how much money I raise.  Instead, we are going to have stretch goals based on how much interest there is in the site (based on the number of "Likes" on www.facebook.com/dungeonshare).  I would rather you donate $5 and try your best to get a few friends interested than to just donate $50 and not tell anyone about it.
With that being said, any money over the $160 will be put to improving the site, finding more modules to generalize, buying ads to expand the user-base, or maybe even commissioning pictures for some of the modules to help players visualize certain situations (also a great way to give work to young artists).
100 Likes => NPC Section Added
If I have 100 people interested in Dungeon Share , I will add a section about (non-enemy) NPCs.  This will help GMs make dynamic and interesting characters for players to interact with.
150 Likes => Traps Section Added
Once we reach 150 likes, I'll add on a trap section to keep every adventurer on their toes and give new GMs a long list of fun ideas.
250 Likes => Items Section Added
With 250 people interested, I'll create an additional section where creative item ideas can be compiled.  This will allow GMs to make items that do more than just buff stats of their players, but actually add to the fun and interactivity of the game.
More goals to come.
Thank you for considering my project, and I hope to see your support!  If you want to get started early and submit module ideas, email us at dungeonsharesubmit@gmail.com and your name will be featured on whatever module you help create.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
My nightmare situation would be either me getting terribly injured and leaving everyone waiting. I also do not have extensive knowledge in website creation, so someone hacking the page could be a potential risk. Fortunately, there will be no financially valuable information stored on the website at any time, so this is a minimal risk.

Outside of those unlikely disasters, the biggest risk is not having enough support to keep Dungeon Share growing. If it doesn't grow, less people will use the website, which will result in less ad income, which could potentially stop the site from running. This is where I come in; I've run a healthy number of tabletop campaigns (some physically with friends, some online with complete strangers), and I will put every ounce of my creative juice into this site to get it up and running. I can only hope that others will see the utility of the site and decide to do their part.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Dear Wonderful Backers,

Dungeon Share has seen a lot of changes since we first started our journey.  It has had a steadily climbing number of modules, and now allows members to discuss ideas and issues via a simple forum.  It also includes (a few) themes that can make picking out the right modules a little bit easier.

Hey Everyone!

If you haven't been following us on Facebook (and you should), Dungeon Share has been growing rapidly.  We have 200+ modules finished and plenty more on the way.  There is still a ton of room for more, and I'm working hard to get all the categories to have a decent number of modules.

A forum has been added to the site, and I highly recommend you check it out!  More chatter in the forums means more ideas to add to the site which means a bigger, better Dungeon Share.  I hope that we can convince members to make Dungeon Share their forum of choice for GM related advice.

The $10 tiers are taking longer than expected, but I understand people have actual things to do with their lives and can't do everything immediately.  The good news is that the $5 tier really has no dependence on the $10 tier being done, so I'll send those surveys out soon.

Finally, I want to ask for your opinion.  I'm considering adding another drop down to the menu bar that would be"Modules by Theme."  That way, GMs could choose to look at all the modules that fit the "Horror" theme, "Glory in Battle" theme,  "Classic Dungeon Crawl" theme, etc.  Would you use something like this, or would it be a waste of my time to create?

Thank you all for your support, and good luck with your next campaign!
-Chris

P.S.  There is another Kickstarter that I think any GM should look into.  Describing combat in continually interesting ways is something even the most veteran GM can struggle with.  I can't even begin to explain how frustrating it is to hear a GM repeat "The ______ draws back it's sword and slashes at you." for 6 hours straight.

With these cards (and a cool GM screen that was unlocked), you can make storytelling so much easier and more engaging.  Check them out at:

Congratulations Everyone!

Dungeon Share is officially a go... so I'd like to do a quick update as to how I plan on working the next few weeks.

The surveys will start out going to the top tier.  It's not because I love them more, but rather because I want the $10 tier to have as many categories as possible to choose from.   Expect those surveys soon!

In the meanwhile, the site will continue with regular (probably daily) updates.  There will be slight face-lift to the menu to allow more categories, but nothing mind blowing.  You can find out the details of those updates by checking the home page, or by checking our face book page.

Thanks for all your support!
-Chris

To all of my fantastic backers,

With two days left, we've got just enough time for one last big shove of support.  I'd love to be able to say we started out with 50 people willing to pledge their hard earned money to see this site succeed.  Getting to 200% funding would also be amazing, and would allow Dungeon Share much more time to reach self-sufficiency.

After an annoying day of dealing with the car shop to get my tires replaced, I was overwhelmed to find that we had jumped up over $50 in one day!

With our funding now over 150%, we will be able to make sure Dungeon Share stays hosted for at least an additional half of a year!  During this time, we will continue to build a following for the site and continue to reinvest any profits from advertisements into making the site better.  I refuse to take any of the profits until the site reaches self-sufficiency.  With any luck, those 18 months (and counting) will be enough time to gather a strong following to make Dungeon Share a permanent resource.

To my wonderful backers:
I decided that halfway through our time together is a great time to give a quick update on the progress of the site.  We now have a total of about 75 modules spanning 6 categories (and two more mystery categories eventually being added by backers so far).  The site gets about 25 hits a day, so the good news is that people are actually using it.

I've come to doubt the legitimacy of using Kickstarter funds to hold any sort of raffle, so I've decided to make use of some of my own gift cards I've yet to use to get the flow of ideas started.  However, I can not stress enough how important collaboration is to make Dungeon Share a success.  Whenever I Google similar sites, I find a graveyard of websites/blogs with year-old updates practically begging for user submissions.  I've come up with a lot of ideas, but a single imagination is much more limited than that of a community.

Thanks to everyone for making this possible.  We have finally achieved enough to get Dungeon Share up and running.  Here is a quick breakdown of the process now that we have been fully funded.
Site Updates:
Obviously the site will continue to have daily updates. How much each update has will depend on two things: the amount of time in my schedule and the amount of ideas I get from the community.  Creating a module by scratch takes around 30 minutes, while turning an email into a module takes about 20 minutes.  Although this time isn't far off now, it will only get worse as I begin to exhaust my creativity.

Wonderful Supporters,

I wanted to do an official one-week update to let you know some of the progress being made on Dungeon Share.

First of all, I have decided that only counting backers was perhaps a little bit unfair.  After all, there are a lot of people who support the site but don't want to create a Kickstarter account or donate money.  I have thus decided that we will transform the stretch-goals into Facebook likes.  Going by likes on Facebook allows members to support the site for free using an account they probably already have.  To reflect this new definition, NPCs will be unlocked at 100 Likes (We had 94 at the time of posting this), Traps (which I decided to add) will be unlocked at 150 Likes, and Items will be unlocked at 200 Likes.  If for some reason you are backing and don't want to like us at , you can message me and I'll include you in the total.

New Stretch Goal reached: Padauk!
Next stretch goal: $7000 - Inverted boxes, Where the box is the same color as the accents on the Dice Vault, and the splines are the color of the primary wood.
* * *
As we all know, all D20s have a certain number of natural 20s stored in them.  Once this supply is depleted, only rolling critical misses will restore them.  So, how do you protect your supplies of 20s from being stolen by so called 'friends'?  The Cryptex Dice Vault is your solution.  With this attractive cylinder, your dice will be safe and secure!
A cryptex is a form of combination lock and safe all in one.  Only when all of the reels are aligned to the correct positions can the the two cylinders be separated, giving access to the contents hidden within.
Cryptex Dice Vault Prototype
This Cryptex is perfectly sized to hold a standard 7 set of polyhedral for D&D or other similar game systems.  Made of real hardwood, inlayed with contrasting colors and stamped with numbers.  Featuring 5 reels of numbers, the CDV has 100,000 possible combinations.
Dark World - Holds Ten D10
For those of you who enjoy games from the World of Darkness or other D10 based systems, we have the Dark World CDV, a longer version that can handle a full set of ten D10s.
Pride - Same size as the Dark World
The Pride features 7 reels just like the Dark World, but instead of numbers, it features the seven colors of the rainbow.  Due to the need to be painted, the Pride is not available in hardwood.
The Pride will keep your secrets...at least some of them.
Da Vinci
And finally there's the largest of the vaults, the Da Vinci.  Unlike the others, which feature just the numbers 0-9, the Da Vinci features larger reels with the full A-Z alphabet.  The Da Vinci has a similar length as the basic CDV, but a larger internal cross section.
Matching Case
Each of the vaults is available alone, or with a custom fitted box of matching wood.
CDV in case

Each of the dice vaults is available in your choice of three different woods, elm, walnut, and purpleheart.

So, why Kickstarter?  I have developed a good method for producing these vaults, but there are some errors due to my available tools.  Upon completion of this kickstarter, I will be able to purchase several tools that will greatly aid in production, in particular a thickness planer.
 Note: The images displayed here are prototypes and may change slightly in the final design.

International Orders
Due to repeated requests, I have added options for those outside the US who might be interested.  The increased prices are due to the high cost of international shipping costs.  Please note that the buyer is responsible for any customs fees that may occur, so please take this into account before pledging.

Shipping to the USA
If you are located in the USA and want to pledge, do not select any option marked "INTERNATIONAL".  These reward levels have international shipping costs built in, and cannot be refunded.  If you make a mistake, you can change your pledge level before the Kickstart ends.

Frequently Asked Questions
Can the combination be changed?
The combination cannot be changed after manufacturing. I plan to create a survey upon completion of the Kickstarter that will allow pledgers to specify the combination of their choice, but that combination can't be changed after that point.
Will you ship internationally?
Yes, due to popular demand, I have added an international option.  The higher cost of international shipping is included in the pledge level.  However, any customs fees are the responsibility of the receiver.
What if I want more than one?
Increase your pledge by the appropriate amount and indicate what the additional portion is for.  I also hope to allow for the purchase of additional units once the kickstarter has ended.

updates.update_content:
This update is a long time coming. Part of it was trying to come up with the right words, but I admit that much of it is simply embarrassment. I am embarrassed because I have failed to keep up my end of the bargain, both the promise of regular updates, and regular progress.
The lack of updates is clear, of course. The lack of progress is less so. Over the last few months, I have made very little headway on this project, and I don’t think that is likely to change. I was overly ambitious in this Kickstarter, and inexperienced. It’s time to admit failure. It would be unfair to keep dragging this out any longer, making promises that I don’t believe I will be able to keep. I should have admitted this months ago, but I wanted to believe I could finish everything.

Here is the update (barely in time, i.e. late) for August.  The reason I'm so late is that I don't really have much to say.  I'm afraid August was very non-productive for me.  This is in part due to some family obligations that came up and some long work hours, but mostly it was just due to my own fault with time management.
As summer winds down, I hope to correct this.  Thank you all for your patience.  If you no longer wish to wait, send me a note asking for a refund and I will send you one. I will need a paypal address from you as well.

Hey everyone, hope you're having a good July.
I'm continuing to work on things as much as I can, although things have been a little slow due to us moving to a new building at my other job.  But the upside is that I get to claim a couple solid wood drafting tables that will make excellent workbenches for my shop.  I'm going to be taking the weekend to do some much needed cleaning and reorganization, and then get back into production.

Hey everyone, thanks for the recent comments. I had intended to post an update a while ago, but then I got sick, and after that got distracted by other things. 
After a sporadic winter, it's finally getting to be springtime here in Montana, excellent weather to work in the shop.  I did continue to work in the colder weather, but it's a lot more comfortable when the weather is nice.

Hello everyone.  I realize this is the first update in quite a while.  I have been making a few notes in the comment section, but I realize not everyone reads those.  Progress continues, slower than I'd like.  A few more were completed last month, but as I mentioned in the comments, I was unavailable for much of the time.
Here's a few pictures of ongoing things.  First is an example of some of the issues I've run into.  It turns out that purpleheart is very pretty, but tends to splinter a bit when I take it to the router.  Padauk and Walnut have similar issues, but it seems worse in purpleheart.

Hello everyone!
Been busy working lately and before I knew it a few months passed with no updates, and here we are at the 1 year anniversary of the project.
I really hoped that everyone would have their box by this point (or well before this point) but sadly this has not happened.  I'm continuing to work on these and sending them off as time allows.

The holidays were pretty disruptive as expected, but I'm back into the swing of things, sending out the cryptexes as soon as I get a batch done.  Thank you for your patience, I know it's been a long wait, far longer than I originally estimated.
I recently was able to get a dust collector for my shop.  Once installed, it will make a lot of aspects of the cutting easier, cleaner, and with any luck, slightly faster.

Once again, I'm afraid I must apologize with the lack of updates on this project.  I meant to get in some progress reports, but I kept holding off in the hope of having something better to report.

Help bring this George R. R. Martin Masterworks major line expansion to market! These are all lead-free Pewter Miniatures - not plastic. The miniatures shown are the actual original sculpts.

Congratulations - We funded in 132 minutes and are deep into Stretch Goals!
If you ever thought that Tre Manor (Red Box Games) and Kev White (Hasslefree) should be sent to the wall to live out their lives and protect the realm - now you have your wish. Kev White sculpted these two wonderful tribute miniatures up.
These tribute sculpts are pending final approval by GRRM as George personally signs off on each miniature in the range. Tre Manor is on the left and Kev White on the right by the way.
For our next stretch goal backers will receive a second FREE copy of the popular new Young Hedge Knight sculpt for FREE.
This sculpt is pending final approval by GRRM as George personally signs off on each miniature in the range.

Dark Sword has been producing the critically acclaimed George R.R. Martin Masterworks range of tabletop gaming scale pewter miniatures at a very measured pace over the past 6+ years. About a miniature a month is what it has broken down to.  These miniatures are created working closely with George himself from how he envisioned the characters from the books in his mind - they are not from the HBO series. George personally approves every single sculpt as he is an avid miniature collector (his personal collection is beyond epic)  and has quite the eye for what he wants in this line. With your backing and support on this project, we would like to increase this pace and come out with a very large expansion of new miniatures in one unified release for the range in early 2014.
The legendary Tom Meier (from Ral Partha fame) has sculpted up this truly exceptional expansion set of miniatures.  Tom Meier has been a Dark Sword team member since 2004 and is the lead sculptor on the GRRM Masterworks range.
Above is a comprehensive graphic that showcases everything our Early Bird and Westeros Level Backers receive for FREE and also have access to in the form of optional add-ons. For more detailed information, please see our Updates section above.
For those of you unfamiliar with Dark Sword Miniatures and the style of our gaming scale miniatures (what would be referred to as 28mm Heroic Scale from many companies), you can check us out on our Web site at: www.DarkSwordMiniatures.com You can also scroll down the page to some gallery pictures of a small sampling of the miniatures we have released over the past 12 years. Please note - these are painted studio model examples – all of our miniatures come in bare pewter or resin and will require minor assembly. You the hobbyist will get the pleasure of assembling and painting our miniatures in whatever color schemes you wish to see them in. It is a wonderful hobby indeed..
Dark Sword has already run and fully delivered on a Kickstarter we ran back in July/August 2013. We aim to once again exceed expectations on delivery of this project both on the quality of our miniatures and speed of delivery for our backer rewards. Like our last Kickstarter project, we have a very simple campaign backer structure you can see over to your right. Early Bird and Westeros Backers will be rewarded for their support with special Kickstarter pricing that includes shipping in the USA and extra perks like a signed and numbered certificate of authenticity from George R.R. Martin, Tom Meier and Jim Ludwig. Other perks will include stretch goals that can be unlocked along the way for more free bonus miniatures added into the core set and access to other cool add-ons after the initial funding goal is exceeded. Our first free bonus miniature stretch goal is already unveiled - the man himself at his Westeros writing desk. Please note - International shipping is very expensive so our friends outside of the USA will have a nominal shipping charge applied to their pledge – this simply helps defray our shipping costs overseas – Dark Sword is not profiting off of shipping costs.
As you can see from the introduction video and pictures of the miniatures above, we already have the core set fully sculpted and have been running test castings of these miniatures to ensure everything is ready to crank into high gear on the production front once we get underway. Everything is cast in lead-free pewter. We aim to have backer rewards delivered very quickly after this campaign is finished so people can enjoy these amazing miniatures.
Below is a small sampling of our existing George R.R. Martin Masterworks Pewter Miniature range from the Song of Ice and Fire Book Series that inspired the hit HBO show Game of Thrones. These miniatures were created working closely with GRRM himself from how he envisioned the characters from the books in his mind - they are not from the HBO series. Please note - these are painted studio models - all of our miniatures come in bare pewter or bare resin and require minor assembly and of course painting.
Below is a small sampling of our Elmore Masterworks Pewter Miniature range. Please note - these are painted studio models - all of our miniatures come in bare pewter or bare resin and require minor assembly and of course painting.
Below is a small sampling of our Visions in Fantasy Pewter Miniature range. Please note - these are painted studio models - all of our miniatures come in bare pewter or bare resin and require minor assembly and of course painting.
Below is a small sampling of our Visions in Fantasy Anthropomorphic Animal (I call them critters) Pewter Miniature range. Please note - these are painted studio models - all of our miniatures come in bare pewter or bare resin and require minor assembly and of course painting.
We have included the above galleries of images to showcase a small sampling of what Dark Sword Miniatures has delivered over the past 12 years as we approach 600 miniatures produced. You can see for yourself the quality and care we put into every aspect of our small boutique miniature company.  You can check out our Web site at: www.DarkSwordMiniatures.com to see more examples of what we have done and also read customer testimonials about the quality of our miniature ranges and the speed of our shipments all over the world. I bring these things up to call attention to our proven track record of delivering on projects in a consistent methodical manner.
Some folks have asked for size comparison pictures next to Reaper Miniatures. So I have taken some pictures (forgive the rough lighting here as it was simply sun coming in the window for our light source) of some of our new and existing GRRM miniatures next to some Reaper Bones and Reaper Metal minis.
Male Miniatures Size Comparision Between Reaper Miniatures and Dark Sword Miniatures
Female Miniatures Size Comparision Between Reaper Miniatures and Dark Sword Miniatures
Please keep in mind that GRRM goes to great lengths to differentiate and describe his characters in regards to their heights and overall sizes/shapes. You have the extremes from Tyrion up to Ser Gregor "The Mountain That Rides" and a good number of very tall strong men in between like Jaime Lannister, The Black Fish and the Old Bear. Tom Meier and Jeff Grace go into exacting detail to get this across on very small miniatures. Even differences between Dany and Sansa compared to the much taller Cersei or Melisandre are evident in these minis.
Thank you very much for checking out our Kickstarter Project!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The biggest challenge we face is getting the backer rewards shipped in a timely and affordable fashion. I want to exceed expectations on this front once again like we did on our first Kickstarter with the Elmore Dragon Special Edition Diorama Set. So to once again help support this goal, we have already completed sculpting and initial molding on the core set of miniatures. We have also performed test castings to ensure everything is dialed in from a pewter quality perspective. We have already had our pewter miniature caster set aside casting time and packing time so we can quickly get a head start on production as this campaign is underway. Just like with our first Kickstarter, we will keep our backers in the loop with frequent updates throughout the run of this new Kickstarter project. All of our production and packing/shipping will take place in/from the Midwest USA.

Many Kickstarter campaigns also run into shipping issues – especially international shipping issues. We are in our 12th year of business and have shipped orders out all over the world in the past 12 years. We also completed and fully delivered on our first Kickstarter in August 2013. International shipping is expensive and this large release will be no exception. Dark Sword Miniatures has built a reputation of top notch quality and dependability over the years in regards to both our miniatures and our shipping turn times. And we aim to build upon that reputation once again with this new Kickstarter. 

Another challenge many Kickstarters face is sorting the surveys after the project completes. Just like our last Kickstarter, we have purposely built our project with simplified backer levels in order to simplify surveys so they are easy to complete and return quickly.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
I'm bringing some important information back to the top of the page. Please read this before finalizing your pledge.

BUY 4 GET 1 FREE PROGRAM
Many of you are asking about the Buy 4 get 1 free offer. In a nutshell, it works as follows:
Choose your 5 cases: They can be of any wood, of any style, of any size.
Determine which is your free case: Your free case must be of a domestic wood (oak, poplar, cedar, maple, cherry, black walnut, or curly maple). The free case can be the 2nd most expensive case you are getting (if you are getting 3 bloodwood, a maple and an oak, the Maple case is free since it is a domestic wood that is not the most expensive.)
Use the pledge calculator to determine your pledge: Click on the link below and put in your four cases that you will be paying for. At the end of the project I'll send you a survey where you can give me details on all your cases
Do you have to pay for epoxy or engraving upgrades on the free case? If you are getting epoxy finishes or engraving on the boxes you pay for, you do not need to pay for this upgrade on your free case. If you want your free case to have upgrades that your other cases do not have, then yes, you will have to pay for those upgrades.
Pledge the correct amount in an appropriate tier: you can either pledge in the buy 4 get one free tier, or in a tier of an appropriate hardwood. It won't matter in the end. I'll be in contact with your at the end of the project to get details.
Tell your friends: quickly. This project ends in just a few hours. At the end of the project, when I start selling these on a retail basis, most prices will probably go up. Now is the time to get these at a great price.

Contact links
Go to my Facebook Page
**Please scroll to the bottom to see UNLOCK information! The project will start with one bonus already unlocked!**
**Please click here to go to the Pledge Calculator**
Directions:
1. download the google doc as an excel spreadsheet
2. fill out the form
3. pledge the amount listed on the TOTAL column at the pledge level of the highest tier for which you qualify.
I am now part of the Kicking it Forward program. 5% of my profits will be pledged to other kickstarter projects. For more info, please see this website: http://kickingitforward.org
YOU ASKED FOR IT, NOW YOU GET IT!
In the above pictures, you can see the comparative size of the PRIEST line of cases. It measures 8" x 12" and can hold up to 3x the number of figures as the ROGUE case can. at 8" x 12", it is still smaller than most laptop computers, so it is transportable without being too bulky.
The padding pictured is the standard sea-foam green offered at the local craft store. This is the only color that was available to me to make this prototype. When the product ships, it will come with charcoal grey padding. This is the only color I can buy at wholesale pricing. (Believe me, I've looked for other colors. I originally wanted to offer red/blue/green/etc.)
Due to the construction method (milling from a single piece of wood), this case can only be made from wood that I can get in boards at least 9" wide. This will mean that at least in this offering, I will have to limit the boxes to the woods that I know I can get in that thickness. If you must have the box in "xyz" wood, drop me a line and I'll confirm whether I can get that type of wood. There would probably be a minimum order of 3 boxes in that case so that I know I'm going to be able to cover the cost of the boards.
Which brings us to the issue of pricing. The PRIEST has more than twice the surface area as the ROGUE and will take considerably longer to mill, do artwork on, and will take twice the amount of poly/epoxy to finish. The PRIEST cases will hold 3x the number of minis that the ROGUE line does. Yet, despite all that, I am offering the PRIEST at a price which will give you more bang for the buck. The pricing for the standard (no artwork, polyurethane finish) unit is:
PRIEST ACOLYTE:     Red Oak 8x12 case  $40
PRIEST ADEPT:     Poplar 8x12 case   $40
PRIEST CURATE:    Maple 8x12 case    $45
PRIEST PERFECT:   Cherry 8x12 case   $50
PRIEST CANON:     Curly Maple 8x12 case: $55 
PRIEST PATRIARCH: Purpleheart 8x12 case: $60
PRIEST CARDINAL: Brazilian Cherry 8x12 case: $60
PRIEST BISHOP: Bloodwood 8x12 case: $85
PRIEST ZEBRAWOOD: Zebrawood 8x12 case: $90
Artwork and finish upgrades are available with these, just as with the rogue cases. Rather than do a "plus" and "Deluxe" level as I did with the ROGUE cases, I decided just to keep the above tiers. Artwork and Epoxy will be handled as an add-on.
If you want artwork (Celtic Shield, Sword and Shield, Doomed Princess line art, or Doomed Princess engraving), it will cost an additional $10. If you want an epoxy finish upgrade (this includes inlay if applicable), add an additional $20 to your pledge.
Example: if you want a PRIEST ADEPT (Poplar) with Celtic Shield with Garnet Red inlay and epoxy finish, you would pledge $70 for one case ($40 for the case + $10 for the artwork + $20 for the epoxy)
Finally, since I know someone will ask the question: Does the "buy 4 get 1 free" deal apply to the PRIEST line of cases? 
The answer is "yes", under the same restrictions as before. Your free case will need to be equal to or less in value than the most expensive case that you paid for and be made from a DOMESTIC wood. If your most expensive case is $40, then your free case cannot exceed a value of $40. And yes, you can mix and match ROGUE  and PRIEST cases to get your free case. Please figure up your total pledge and pledge that amount in the "buy four get one free" reward tier.
thanks to everyone for helping me make this project a success!
STRETCH GOALS
Introducing the Rogue line of miniature cases
The Rogue line of cases are small transport cases for about 10 human-sized 28mm miniatures. They are made from hardwoods selected for their beauty and grain pattern and measure 5" x 8". Both the top and the bottom of the boxes have 1/2" foam padding providing a tight fit for your miniatures.
I've always enjoyed playing games. I started playing D&D back in the late 70s, played through high school and college, and now play games with my kids. I recently backed one of the Reaper projects and ended up pledging enough for somewhere around 200 miniatures. While I wait (impatiently) for these miniatures, I started thinking about how I would store them. My old D&D figures (of which I still have some) have sat in their old boxes, getting batted around, slowly losing paint and wearing down over the years because of the cut-outs in the foam that allow the figures to bounce around every time I pick up the box. Using my woodworking skills, I decided to build a box that would keep the miniatures secure and be a work of art that in itselfwould enhance the gaming experience.
What makes the Rogue special?
First and foremost, Rogue cases are made from very high quality pieces of wood. I do not use plywood or mdf, laser-cut pieces out for the customer to assemble, and call it a quality box. The top half of the box and the bottom half of the box are milled from a single piece of hardwood. What does this mean to you? It means there are no joints that can break over time. There are no weak points that may loosen with use. It is a solid piece of wood that captures all the beauty of natural hardwood.
Second, I use quality hinges and clasps for the boxes. I want these boxes to look good and last for a long time. I want, when you open the box at your next gaming session, for your friends to see that you take the game seriously enough to protect your miniatures.
Lastly, I give you the option of original art being laser engraved on your box. In this Kickstarter project, I am going to offer the Rogue boxes in your choice of 4 patterns: Normal, Celtic Shield, Sword and Shield, and Doomed Princess. These patterns and drawings are the creation of my daughter, a fellow gamer and aspiring artist.
What woods can I choose from?
I am initially offering these boxes in various Appalachian hardwoods. You can choose from poplar, red oak, cherry, hard maple, aromatic cedar (yes, not a hardwood), black walnut, and curly maple. 
Once the initial goal has been reached, I will start unlocking other types of wood. Exotic woods are highly popular right now and I do have a source for many of these woods. As each new goal is reached, a new wood will be unlocked.
 What Add-ons are available?
As I wrote earlier, there are four different versions of each wood case. The first is the plain wood that is pictured above. This is simply the case with a high gloss finish. It will show the natural beauty of the wood, and you get this with your minimum pledge.
But if you wish to add a decoration to your case, you can do so by pledging in the appropriate "plus" category. You can choose which decoration you want: "Celtic Shield" or "Sword and Shield." These decorations will be laser engraved onto the top of the case and then sealed with a high gloss finish. Below are examples of each type of engraving. Please note that the engraving shows up better in some woods than in others.
  *NOTE: wood used for the Apprentice boxes will not be made from boards that have knots in them like the one pictured above. This was one of my first prototypes and I was using scrap wood. The boxes will be made from wood that is clear or has minimal knots.
If you want your case to really shine you can get your box engraved and a colorful inlay added. I use a tinted 2 part epoxy as inlay material for the decorations that will harden and permanently adhere to the design. The top is then treated with a thick clear coat similar to what is used on bar tops. This epoxy finish is the equivalent of about 50 coats of polyurethane finish. 
Colors available for this are Metallic Black, Sapphire Blue, Garnet Red, Pearl White, and Metallic Copper.
You can select these options simply by choosing the appropriate Deluxe tier on the right.
 A few notes on the images above:
I was trying different methods to add color to the designs. In a few of them, I had to sand too much to get rid of excess material. The result was that the walnut, red oak and cedar examples had virtually no surface difference between the design and the surrounding wood. This is why the colored material does not look consistent. The cherry and polar pieces were the last two I did and there was minimal waste and sanding, thus a better looking finish. Now that I have the technique down, I fully expect results for all woods to be consistent with the cherry and poplar examples. Regardless, I will not allow an item to be shipped that I personally would not be proud to display as my own. 
I am also posting two pictures here that attempt to show the mirror-like surface of an epoxy finish. While these are "bad pictures," they show how polished the surface looks.
Also available in the Deluxe tier, I am offering an original piece of art laser engraved on your case. This laser art CANNOT be inlaid, but is sealed with the epoxy finish giving it a mirror-like surface. The artwork being offered is titled "Doomed Princess." These are also part of the "Deluxe" tiers. At the end of the project, I will send a form to everyone where you can specify if you want "Doomed Princess" or if you want one of the other designs. Remember, there is no color inlay available with this. In my opinion, the best wood that shows the illustration is Maple, although poplar, oak, and cherry are good as well. I would not recommend doing this drawing with black walnut or other dark woods.
Doomed Princess with Glare
*NOTE: Sometimes it is difficult to show in a picture the mirror-like surface of an epoxy coating. The above picture was taken with a light source purposely shining on it to give you an idea of how reflective this surface can be.
Finally, due to requests from users who have previewed this project, I am going to offer an opportunity to laser inscribe YOUR original artwork onto a box. You must provide me with a high resolution scan of original art (not copyrighted) that I will laser engrave on any Rogue case.
I have to stress that this MUST be either original artwork, or work that you personally hold the copyright to. My primary job is in publishing and know first hand the pitfalls of copyright violation. Before I begin work on the project you will be required to sign a permissions release form that will, in essence, cover my bases if there is a copyright violation.
I've been trying to think of a fair way of handling this. I originally had set up a tier where the original artwork box would cost $100 and thereafter it would be less expensive to have this done. After talking with a friend today, I decided to change this a little. Instead of having the high price on the initial case, I am going to treat original artwork as an add-on feature.
If you want to have your own art (be it a drawing or line art) featured on your case, you would pledge at the level at which you would normally, but then you would need to pledge an additional $25 as an add-on price. This cost will cover the added time and (likely) test run of the piece of art. This $25 setup fee is a one time add-on. So, if you wanted 3 cases at the Magsman Deluxe level with your custom artwork, the final price would be $175 ($50 each for the Magsman Deluxe plus a $25 setup fee)
Multiple case purchase
If you are interested in multiple cases, select the level to the right for the proper case, and then add in the extra add-ons for additional cases. For example, if you are interested in 2 walnut cases with Metallic Copper Celtic shields and one red oak with the Celtic shield engraved (no epoxy), you would pledge at the Sharper Deluxe level for $115 (2 Sharper Deluxe for $45 each plus 1 Apprentice Plus for $25).
Also note that I'm starting the project with one free unlock! Pledge enough for 4 cases, and get the 5th for free! So go ahead and get those two extra cases with your pledge!
IMPORTANT: if you want to pledge for 4 cases and get the 5th on for free, please pledge at the $1 BUY FOUR GET 1 FREE level. This will make the post-project system easier to implement. If you pledge for 5 items at a different level, the check-out cart will not know how to figure your free box.
NOTE: If you pledge enough for the "buy 4 get 1 free", the free case cannot be an exotic wood. The materials cost is just too high for the free case to be an exotic.
What are the funds being raised for?
Funds will be used for purchasing wood and hardware in quantity enough for wholesale pricing, paying for the laser work to be done (or the purchasing of a laser engraver if the project does well enough), and upgrading a room of my workshop into a dedicated finishing room. The finish of the boxes is perhaps the most important, yet frequently the most overlooked, part of a wood project. I use a high gloss lacquer or polyurethane for finishing most of my wood projects and without a clean room for finishing, dust particles can mar an otherwise beautiful project. I want the Rogue to have a finish that captures all the beauty of the wood; and to do that I need a room separate from the one where I make the box.
 Unlock information:
1. Multiple Box Unlock: If you pledge enough for 5 boxes, you get a discount equal to the average pledge per case. For example, if you pledge so you would receive 2 Cutpurse cases (Maple), 1 cutpurse plus (maple with design), and 2 Magsman Deluxe (Curly Maple with epoxy), the normal pledge amount would be $180, but this would be discounted $36 for a total pledge amount of $144. Pledge calculator is here
PLEASE NOTE: THE FREE CASE CANNOT BE AN EXOTIC WOOD! THE MATERIALS COST IS JUST TOO HIGH FOR ME TO DO THIS. Thank you for understanding.
2. *UNLOCKED*: Purpleheart unlock at $1,500: When $1,500 in pledges is reached, purpleheart wood will be unlocked. This is a wood found in Central or South American rainforests with a rich purple heartwood. It is naturally extremely dense and water resistant.
 3. UNLOCKED!! Brazillian Cherry: At $2,500, Brazillian cherry will be unlocked. Brazilian cherry is a common Caribbean and South American. It is frequently used in flooring, and it is also a popular wood for furniture. It is dark brown/red in color.
4.  UNLOCK: My facebook page has a meager number of likes. Help me get to 50 friends and you can choose between Felt backing (so you can use your box as a dice tray) or the foam padding so you can use it for miniatures.
5. UNLOCKED!!!! Doomed Princess line art UNLOCK: Get "Doomed Princess" as line art so it can be colorized with epoxy. This can be chosen for any "plus" or "Deluxe" level pledge.
 6. UNLOCK!! At $3,000 Paduak wood is unlocked. Padauk is an African hardwood with a brown-red color. It is very hard and very stable (resistant to warp due to moisture changes).
 7 UNLOCKED!!!: At $4,000 Bloodwood is unlocked. Bloodwood is a South American hardwood that has a bloody-red color. It is extremely dense and durable.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Most of the risks in a project like this is what happens if the project is TOO successful. I can make a fair number of boxes at a time, and my equipment is reliable enough, that I don't have a lot of worry about being able to manufacture any reasonable amount of orders. But everyone on Kickstarter has seen the projects that just go viral and suddenly a small business has more orders than it normally sees in a year.

I hope that this is a problem I have, yet I don't want the success of the Rogue to mean the delay in shipping of everyone's orders. By watching other projects, I plan to institute a limit to each tier of support so I can ship in waves. This limit will not mean that I will stop producing that particular type of wood, but rather that the shipments will be designated to occur later than the original shipment date. So, a Wave 1 shipment date will be in May. If I need a Wave 2 shipment, it will be scheduled for one month later, giving me sufficient time to process and construct the cases. Further waves will be scheduled according to my projections on when I believe I can complete the orders.

Depending upon the success of the project, I may also use an online form creation program which will allows me to contact each sponsor in order for them to fill out a form telling me precisely what type of wood, what designs, what color accent or type of finish they desire. In this way, I can ensure that each supporter receives the box they want with the appropriate finish.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Hi there! We're the Doubleclicks. Thanks to this Kickstarter, we are going to make a lot of awesome things this year! Backers will be able to follow along on our progress on the CD, videos & more via updates! You can also check us out at http://thedoubleclicks.com and watch our videos on our YouTube channel! To be kept up to date on songs, the album, and our live shows around the country, subscribe to our e-mail list! 
Thank you for unlocking all these stretch goals!
Future stretch goals:
There are more details about all of these goals below!
Hi, we’re the Doubleclicks, and we write songs about things like dinosaurs, Dungeons & Dragons, love, books, and cats. We also have a cello, and we’re sisters. You may know us from performing at conventions around the country, from many songs and collaborations (including the theme song for Cards Against Humanity), or from our big geek girl pride music video that came out last year, "Nothing to Prove," full of amazing geek girls and some of our nerdy friends.
We want to make a new album this year called “Dimetrodon”, featuring songs we've written over the past year, with studio-quality production and full-band arrangements. We also want to bring back our “Weekly Song Wednesday” music video project this summer. And to do these things, we need help!
We've got some rewards, many of which are exclusive to backers of this Kickstarter! We have t-shirts, dice, copies of the new CD, tote bags, custom songs (and mini meowing-themed-ringtone-songs), and even the opportunity to be immortalized in an art poster that is included with every CD! But even if you can only donate a little, you'll be contributing to our ability to make more and greater things, and we appreciate it!! 
The more money we get, the more exciting things we can produce this year.  We have plenty of ideas on how to turn money in to FUN(ny). Funny? Yes. So take a look at the project, and please share it with your friends—we can't do it without you! We are extremely thankful that you let us make music for you, and we want to do it forever. FOREVER. 
 The Dimetrodon Album
Dimetrodon will be our 3rd full-length album and the second with a "full band studio sound." We want to do this one bigger and better than any album we've done before. We'll be working with pros on the arrangement, mixing and production, including musician, comedian, producer and awesome human being Mike Phirman.
Most of the songs on the Dimetrodon album will be our favorite compositions from 2013's Weekly Song Wednesday project, cleaned up, re-organized and arranged for a full-band sound. There will also be a couple brand-new songs on the album as well as some revivals from the Doubleclicks archives. 

Weekly Song Wednesday (unlocked!)
This is how WSW (Weekly Song Wednesday) works: we write a song, we film a video for that song, and we release these videos once a week on Wednesdays for some number of weeks. WSW is a songwriting exercise, a YouTube project, and a really, really fun way for us to make music and share it. Unfortunately, by itself WSW really doesn't break even, and without crowdfunding we just can't put the time and resources into the project to make songs and videos of the quality that we imagine in our brains. This year, we did Weekly Song Wednesday for 14 weeks, from September through December, and it was really fun. Dimetrodon was one of our favorite songs and videos from that project, check it out:
 
If we meet our initial Kickstarter goal, then, in addition to producing the album Dimetrodon, we will launch a new Weekly Song Wednesday project this spring/summer with new songs and videos that we can spend much, much more time on than we could last year. These videos could include good cameras, other people to hold the cameras (crazy, right?), props, costumes, and much more time spent on rehearsal, editing and doing lots of takes. Thanks to your generous backing, Weekly Song Wednesday will now be 10 weeks long instead of our original 5-week goal!
-
 Monthly Song Monday (unlocked!)
We can't do Weekly Song Wednesday all year long: we need to tour, and sleep sometimes, and take breaks to recharge our songwriting muscles. However, we do want to keep releasing things, so at the $35,000 stretch goal, we will unlock a Monthly Song Monday project where we release a new song and video every month (on a monday). This will happen for 12 months, but we will pause this project during the months during which Weekly Song Wednesday is happening and re-start afterwards—so this project will last for longer than a year.
  Monthly Live-Streamed Internet Show (unlocked!)
In Portland, we produce a show called #NerdNightOut in which we fly in our favorite performers from around the country and do an awesome variety show. It happens every few months, but only locally. We'd love to put on a show with our friends and favorite performers everywhere in the world, but we can't. Or can we? If we unlock the $42,000 stretch goal, we will do a monthly live-streamed show (from March 2014 to December 2014). It will be part concert, part chat and part Q&A. We'll also invite our friends to be guests sometimes, so you can hear other people's songs and stories! It will be an Internet-wide Nerd Night "In"! (We're still working on that title). 
-
More awesome stretch goals UNLOCKED
The Doubleclicks coloring and activity book: UNLOCKED
If we reach this $55,000 stretch goal, we’ll make a short Doubleclicks-themed coloring book with help from talented artists! It’ll be a free PDF download for all backers who have selected a reward at level $12 and above, and will feature art by Molly Lewis (singer/songwriter/doodle genius), Ash Vickers (MegaCynics), John Kovalic (of Munchkin, Dork Tower & much more) and Lar DeSouza. There will also be activities included a Mad Lib by author John Scalzi! Here's a sample set of pages by the amazing Molly Lewis:


Animated music video: UNLOCKED!
Our very first video was an animated one, created by the amazing Brad Jonas for our Dungeons & Dragons song. Since then we have wanted to create more, but we just haven't had the resources... until now? At $65,000 one of our videos for Monthly Song Monday videos will be ANIMATED, and it will likely be ADORABLE. Our animator is OnlyLeigh, animator, artist and creator of the excellent webseries FanGirls. Her showreel gives a good idea of how fantastic the video will be: 


Kid's EP: UNLOCKED!
At $75,000, we will write and record a 5-song kids EP (for grown-ups, too) including songs about: science, history, and strong female characters, to be released in 2015. 

There are many many people in the world more qualified to talk about gender issues than we are, but here’s what I know: when I was a kid, in school and church and books, most to all of the heroes I saw were men. Media taught us that boys went off and had adventures and became doctors and scientists, and girls should find themselves a cool man who was a doctor or a scientist, and attract him by wearing uncomfortable dresses and losing weight. We want to make songs that tell a different story. Our goal with the songs on the new EP will be to teach you about things and people you don’t usually learn about. People like Grace Hopper: a computer scientist who basically invented the compiler and, according to legend, discovered the first computer bug (it was an actual bug.) Grace & other awesome people will be featured on this EP, if it's funded. 
Stretch Goal Freeeeeebiiiird!: UNLOCKED!
We can think of no better way to show our appreciation than to succumb to popular demand at the risk of our own sanity: we will cover Lynyrd Skynyrd's "Freebird" and make a video for you, and we will make it fun for ourselves and you. A download of our cover will be available in the 2014 song vault. 

Current Stretch Goal: $80,000 - UNLOCKED!
Thank you all for backing us like crazy!! Even now, your donations are going to help us level-up our music and videos all year. For a final bit of appreciation, we're gonna make you buttons! If we are mailing you anything: a CD, dice, or anything bigger, we will also send you a cool SHINY BUTTON with art by SOMEONE GREAT to show that you are an awesome Kickstarter backer.
The Dimetrodon CD physical package is very exciting for us: we are hiring amazing artist Kris Straub (who makes Broodhollow and Chainsawsuit), of whom we are huge fans, to make the album cover. Here's what his art style looks like:
-
The cover art for the Dimetrodon album will be made by Kris Straub!
The physical CD will also include a pull-out mini-poster created by Lar DeSouza, artist of the webcomics Least I Could Do and Looking for Group. If you back at the "Immortalization" level, a caricature of you (based on one reference photo you provide) will appear in this poster with us!

We are creating three new Doubleclicks custom six-sided dice for this Kickstarter featuring images inspired by this album: a Dimetrodon, a cat, and an image of us, the Doubleclicks! These are designed by the amazing Brian Tatosky!


The 2014 Song Vault is a website where all the songs we write for weekly song wednesday and some other songwriting projects in 2014 will be available for download to backers who unlock it (at the Dimetrodon level and above). You may also find some demos, rarities, and other little ditties we think you'll find fun in this vault. 

T-Shirts and tote bags will feature a Doubleclicks design which is ONLY available through this Kickstarter! The art will be created by webcomic artist Abby Howard of Junior Scientist Power Hour and The Last Halloween! 
T-shirts will be available in adult sizes from S-3XL in a Gildan Unisex Ultra Cotton Tee (sizing) and S-2XL in a "Ladies" Bella Favorite Tee (sizing). Totes will be these jumbo eco-conscious numbers (take a look!). If you select the T-shirt and Tote level or add a T-shirt or tote onto another level for $35 additional, you will be able to choose any size of t-shirt, OR a tote instead, in a survey that we send out after this Kickstarter is over.

  NEW: Dimetrodon Plush!
It's a little baby Dimetrodon plush!!!! This new, special, very exclusive, very cute plush was designed for this Kickstarter and will be individually made just for you by crafting genius Tally Heilke. The fleece Dimetrodon is approx. 17 inches long and soft and friendly. It may or may not eat sharks.
Dimetrodon and “Rawr, Velociraptor” KNITTED HATS! A local here in Portland, Cathy of Frivolite Handcrafts, has created a knitting design for “toque”-style hats with Dimetrodons and Velociraptors on them, and she will be making a set of them for this Kickstarter! You will be able to select size and style. 
Doubleclicks Dice Bags!

RAVENFELL features our exclusive FOLD-FLAT terrain system which allows you to create fully modular 28mm scale village buildings for your RPG or wargame. The buildings are comprised of separate, stackable components, which can be mixed and matched between models for even greater variety, and folded flat for easy storage. Each village set is delivered in a downloadable PDF format via our online distribution partner DriveThruRPG.com, and once you have the set you can print and build as many pieces as you like and never run out or need to purchase more. Additionally, our graphic layer options allow you to customize your building to suit your tastes. This new village set is the culmination of nine years of terrain design experience, combining the best features of our previous sets such as modular components to mix and match, 2D interior tiles (now removable and swappable for maximum versatility) and fold-flat major components, creating the ultimate fantasy village terrain series! All sets include a 1" grid, 1.5" grid, and gridless texture options.
